argument: Dear Nina, with all due respect, one would wonder how the rest of the world survived tens of thousands of years, without the Western diet posited by you! It's worth exploring native (so called primitive) infant weaning practices. Almost every tradition has survived without a western Nestlé premix or infant formula or bottled/jar infant food. Where vegan or vegetarian diets are lacking, consider lentils and millets (example finger millet) which are rich in B vitamins and iron and also easily digestible and biologically available. Please don't dismiss vegan or vegetarian diets for infants so easily. There is a wealth of knowledge available in traditions of Asia, Far East, Africa, Near East, Middle East, you know the rest of the non Eurocentric world!

Where vegan or vegetarian diets are lacking , consider lentils and millets ( example finger millet ) which are rich in B vitamins and iron and also easily digestible and biologically available . Please do n't dismiss vegan or vegetarian diets for infants so easily . There is a wealth of knowledge available in traditions of Asia , Far East , Africa , Near East , Middle East , you know the rest of the non Eurocentric world !

argument: I cannot remember a time when all the invited essays on a Room for Debate, by and large, agreed with each other. These times are lauded as the Age of Information. But the simple reality missing from the premise of this debate is having ACCESS to information is not the same as being able to USE information. A research paper, at its core, requires that information be: > obtained; > analyzed; then > utilized. How could this EVER become obsolete? Yes, it is demoralizing that too many students believe that Google relieves them of any obligation to actually acquire skills of investigation, evaluation, and synthesis or that experts like librarians are obsolete. However, when a graduate program's provides a list of companion articles for courses and then the library provides one-click access to each and every article, they both are complicit in contributing to their own obsolescence.

However , when a graduate program 's provides a list of companion articles for courses and then the library provides one - click access to each and every article , they both are complicit in contributing to their own obsolescence .

argument: Regardless of what other commenters think about Palestine and the Palestinians- some of it blatantly racist e.g. that Arabs are a violent people and therefore not worthy of U.S. support, some of it just historically ignorant- e.g. Arafat turned down a peace deal and therefore Palestinians are undeserving of a state forever after - the issue isn't Palestine v. Israel. The issue is whether the U.S. can be an impartial mediator in the dispute. And it cannot. The U.S., for better or for worse, wrongfully or rightfully, has a 'special relationship' with Israel that will always, always, always come first. Regardless of the current state of affairs, of who is on the 'wrong' or 'right' side of the latest iteration of the conflict, the U.S. is in Israel's corner first and the peace process's second. We therefore can never be a true mediator in this issue.

Israel . The issue is whether the U.S. can be an impartial mediator in the dispute . And it can not . The U.S. , for better or for worse , wrongfully or rightfully , has a ' special relationship ' with Israel that will always , always , always come first . Regardless of the current state of affairs , of who is on the ' wrong ' or ' right ' side of the latest iteration of the conflict , the U.S. is in Israel 's corner first and the peace process 's second . We therefore can never be a true mediator in this issue .

argument: I compete in the Miss America pageant system. In two of my interviews last year, I was asked how I failed and how I overcame that failure. Not only does the Miss America Organization fuel confidence in young women and provides scholarship, but it prepares us for real-world job interviews, public speaking, and brings out the servants' heart in all of us. A huge part of the Miss America Organization is community service. Since 2007, when we first partnered with Children's Miracle Network, the women competing in the organization have raised over $8 million JUST for that one charity. Aside from that, we all have a personal platform that we are advocates for including prevention of diseases, standing up against bullying and breaking stereotypes and barriers that are presented against women. I can't speak for every pageant system, but Miss America is a non-profit organization that is made up by dedicated volunteers. Some incredible women have gone through that organization to go on to incredible careers and futures and a lot of them credit their success to the journey and experience they gained from competing in this program.

Since 2007 , when we first partnered with Children 's Miracle Network , the women competing in the organization have raised over $ 8 million JUST for that one charity . Aside from that , we all have a personal platform that we are advocates for including prevention of diseases , standing up against bullying and breaking stereotypes and barriers that are presented against women . I ca n't speak for every pageant system , but Miss America is a non - profit organization that is made up by dedicated volunteers . Some incredible women have gone through that organization to go on to incredible careers and futures and a lot of them credit their success to the journey and experience they gained from competing in this program .

argument: What part about the First Amendment does the Transit Authority not get? The government may not interfere with freedom of expression. No need to talk about hate speech or other governments or cultures here - we have a culture that offends others because we do not allow any one group to be beyond criticism or protest. An ideal that we do not always live up to, but one which we never cease to strive towards. Free speech is either free or not.

An ideal that we do not always live up to , but one which we never cease to strive towards . Free speech is either free or not .

argument: "Marijuana Is Now Big Business" Wrong - marijuana has been big business for decades. The California Dept. of Agriculture has listed it as the number one cash crop in the state for over 20 years in a row. Now, the business is above ground, where it should be. Regulation, taxation, better education, savings in enforcement and incarceration costs - everybody wins. We are slowly now heading in the right direction - ending the biggest and most widespread wrongful jailing of American citizens since slavery. It can't happen quick enough.

argument: Wrong! Two reasons. One, Malthusianism does not hold, since resource production can go up exponentially too. Two, the population will peak out at 12-15 billion or so, when it will start to shrink, as it has been doing in Europe for decades now. Uncontrolled extrapolation is a trap to avoid.

argument: "Why should a family be saddled with the tax costs of paying for public school if they receive no benefit?" - From Ryan above. A well educated public is what leads our country to economic success, medical advancements, and a more evolved society. So perhaps if you home-school and wish to not pay taxes towards education, you should opt out of any benefit given to you that is created as a by-product of public education.

argument: The US embargo on Cuba only helps maintain the status quo in Cuba while being a self inflicted wound on the US, especially the Gulf States of Alabama, Louisianna and Mississippi. The embargo has throttled down major trade along the Mississippi affecting trade from New Orleans to Chicago. The lost trade and development is astronomical. We must remember that Cuba was one of our most important trading partners at the time the embargo was imposed. The embargo had a direct impact on the decline of southern economies. US policy is driven by emotion rather than any realistic policy that might bring about change. How long must the people of the United States be forced to maintain a foolish policy driven by the self interests of a small politically connected community?

argument: Please note that many many comments in response to this article as well as the article itself sadly lacks an in depth understanding of Deaf people. As distinguished professor Harlan Lane notes in his current book, "People of the Eye: Deaf Ethnicity and Ancestry" viewing Deaf and hard of hearing people as a disabled group ignores the history/traditions, language, social mores and customs of generations of Deaf people. Much of the language, history, and customs which have been carried through Deaf schools and provided Deaf people with access to a truly well-rounded education. In the 1988 Congressional Report on the Commission on the Education of the Deaf one of the primary findings was the problem which "has arisen related to the Education of All-Handicapped Children's Act is widespread misinterpretation of the "Least Restrictive Environment" concept. Too often deaf children have been place in improper educational settings because educational agencies have prioritized placement with nonhandicapped children...(pg. 10) As many of us in the field have noted "inclusion is illusion," that is physical proximity does not assure interaction....and an appropriate education, therefore, is NOT guaranteed to Deaf students via PL 94-142 nor IDEA.

argument: I agree with the poster who said there's no one-size approach to this question. My ideal solution would be to take a vacation without the kids ~and~ the husband. Of course, you don't know my family. You think that's heartless and selfish until I explain that I live with the exasperating reality of a husband with mental illness and five step-kids two of whom also have mental illness, who spend the majority of their time with a mom who has very low standards for her own behavior let alone theirs. Yeah, I know- it's my bed, I'll lie in it. But a couple nights to lie in it alone would be nice.

argument: it hilarious that the states scream for Casino's yet fear legalizing marijuana. Gambling destroys more families than marijuana ever did. Casino's prey far more on those who can least afford to gamble than it does in attracting the extremely wealthy to gamble away what they have in the same percentage terms. Know why ? Rich are rich for a reason, they did not gamble away their chance at success, wasting their money on a dream of striking it rich. Casino's pay terribly low wages for service persons. Casino's in the end cost society more than they can ever generate to the states or federal gov't. Casino's should as they always were be a destination resort to insure those that do gamble can at least afford it. I never saw a poor person at Atlantis in the Bahamas, or Aruba, I cannot say the same for Foxwoods, Atlantic City, or even Las Vegas. At one time Las Vegas was a destination resort, now it too exploits the poor more than taking from tourists I don't gamble, but I do enjoy watching people play, I don't enjoy watching them lose.

argument: I find this a stunning essay. The large banks were teetering on the edge of complete collapse just 5-6 years ago. And he's calling these same banks the best run businesses on the planet? In my view, the banks should have been allowed to fail for their reckless behavior.

argument: I'm guessing electric cars will take off when someone comes up with a $200 portable solar-powered (or wind) recharger that can be wheeled out of the garage and top off the battery OFF THE GRID. argument: Citations rather than arrests for minor crimes still make a lot of sense. But I'm not sure that would have helped here---the guy who commits the same crimes over and over, and resists arrest, is likely to fail to appear in court, and then you're stuck with arrest as a solution. Ultimately, if the perceived price to the individual of defying or ignoring the law is lower than the benefits they think they get from breaking the law, you have a big problem.

Ultimately , if the perceived price to the individual of defying or ignoring the law is lower than the benefits they think they get from breaking the law , you have a big problem .

argument: Bravo! cats with front claws often do terrible damage to furniture. While it is politically correct to object to it, the fact is there will be fewer homes for cats, who will end up being euthanized. The comparison isn't between an imaginary garden of Eden and declawing, but rather the choice is between more feral cats and more put down. Those of us who love cats don't want to see well-meaning humans decree that millions of cats suffer to meet the needs of humans.

argument: The Government has no business controlling its workers' free speech on religoius matters during off-hoursand to attempt to do so amounts to goverment endorsement of which religious practices are acceptable. This is easily demonstrable -- as follows: A person is an adherent to a new religion. This religion believes that the holy books of three large monotheistic religions, Judaism, Christianity and Islam, have been corrupted, have errors and therefore must be cleansed. The required cleansing is done by fire. Each Sabbath, adherents must burn one page of each of the holy books for these faiths. It is a bona-fide belief helf by adherents to this faith. If the government prevents them from conducting their cleansing ceremony because others are offended, then it is clearly taking sides on what does and does not constitute acceptable religous beliefs and practices.

argument: Although I have no idea what studies show about home schooled kids, I do know that, having hired two of them, my impression is not favorable. Both were prima donnas who spent a lot of time complaining about work rules, who thought that they should be able to change work processes to suit them, and who resorted to crying and making scenes to try and get their way with co-workers. The public school system was established primarily as a benefit to society, not just the individual child. That is why we all pay taxes to the schools whether we have kids or not. If people want to take their children out, so be it -- but they still still have their obligation to support the schools.

The public school system was established primarily as a benefit to society , not just the individual child . That is why we all pay taxes to the schools whether we have kids or not . If people want to take their children out , so be it -- but they still still have their obligation to support the schools .

argument: "Why would any server go out of his way to give excellent service when he knows he'll be getting the same pay regardless of whether he busts his hump or takes it relatively easy by doing just enough to meet the minimum standards?" And without tipping, I betunhappy customers would communicate that fact directly to management, instead of just to the individual server via dollar bills.

argument: Aron (#36) is right. Not every part of the educational system here in the U.S. is broken. Only those parts that serve the poor are broken. Mr. Canada's suggestion might well be necessary for the schools he oversees. But most schools don't have the same problems, and for them a longer school day seems unnecessary. To bridge the achievement gap, we need to bring the bottom up. The top is for the most part where it ought to be.

To bridge the achievement gap , we need to bring the bottom up . The top is for the most part where it ought to be .

argument: All income should be taxed the same. It shouldn't matter how the money got there. I can imagine that capital gains might be adjusted for inflation. Still, charging 15% for capital gains, or less, as has been proposed, diminishes society's value of work. Work creates concrete economic growth, manipulating money doesn't. At worst it just creates more debt.

At worst it just creates more debt .
